Technical Proficiency

What is the overall quality of your code like?

4/5

The code that I wrote from scratch (magnifier, toolbar rearranging) followed a logical flow and was generally quality code. Problems arose when modifying existing code (state manager, settings gui) as these were a lot more ridgid and hard to change without just sticking code in where it fits.

Overall I'd say I personally wrote quality code, but as always there's room for improvement.

How well did you follow best practices in development?

3/5

We generally lacked any testing beyond user testing, it is a lot harder to write unit tests for such an interactive application, but some may have helped us

We had weekly meetings to make sure we were all on the right track, this insured we had minimal communication issues

I wish I did more refactoring early on. Refacting the main state-manager of the application could have made a lot of things go faster

How well did you use appropriate version control?

4/5

We used version control a lot throughout the whole project, we started off a bit slow, but once we got the hang of it, we were regually merging.

Personally, I was always commiting my work to make sure the repo had my latest changes.

To what extent do you think you contributed an equal portion of the overall project?

5/5

I think I contributed the most to the project, this is fine as I had the most experience working with the codebase and it's what we agreed on.

I was the only person able to make a lot of the changes we wanted (within a decent timeframe) and I always completed my tasks.

Professional proficiency

How often do you attend scheduled group meetings/scrums?

5/5

I don't believe I ever missed a scheduled meeting

How well did you communicate with others in your group or subgroup?

4/5

I always talked up if I had a question or issue during the meetings.

During the week, I'd often send a Slack message if I needed to talk to someone else in the group

How well did you document your work throughout the project?

3/5

I'd always mark my tasks of on Trello when I had completed one. I'd always write appropriate git commit messages.

I'd try to write code commennts if working on brand new code, but would often not comment if I was simply modifying existing code.

How well did you respond to problems or changing requirements?

5/5

If there was a new feature that needed to be added, I always was able to get it added in a quick timeframe.

Just a few of the my completed tasks being marked as completed on Trello
My Git repo commit history. Some comments on some code I wrote.

Sam Medlock, Portfolio, Project 2
